tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating a numerical value based on the Rankine half-body flow model. It involves understanding the relationship between uniform flow, line source, and stagnation points, and requires multiple steps to determine the velocity and distance. Since it involves multiple concepts and a multi-step solution, the difficulty is medium and GPT-5.1 is recommended.

answer_validation.reasoning: The flow is modeled as a superposition of a uniform stream of speed U_\infty and a 2-D line source of strength m located a distance s downstream of the front stagnation point. On the x-axis upstream of the stagnation point, the local velocity is the sum of the uniform flow and the induced velocity of the source. For a 2-D source at the origin, the radial velocity is v_r = m/(2\pi r). Along the negative x-axis (upstream), the radial direction is opposite to the positive x-direction, so the x-velocity is u = U_\infty - m/(2\pi r). The stagnation point occurs where u = 0, giving r_{stag} = m/(2\pi U_\infty). The source is at x = 0, so the stagnation point is at x = -s with s = r_{stag} = m/(2\pi U_\infty). A point P is located further upstream at distance d from the stagnation point, so its coordinate relative to the source is r_P = s + d. The x-velocity at P is u_P = U_\infty - m/(2\pi (s + d)). Using m/(2\pi) = U_\infty s from the stagnation condition, we get u_P = U_\infty - U_\infty s/(s + d) = U_\infty \left(1 - \frac{s}{s + d}\right) = U_\infty \frac{d}{s + d}. The problem states that at P the oncoming stream reaches 90% of its undisturbed velocity, so u_P = 0.9 U_\infty. Hence 0.9 = d/(s + d). Solving gives 0.9(s + d) = d \Rightarrow 0.9s + 0.9d = d \Rightarrow 0.9s = 0.1d \Rightarrow d/s = 9. This matches the official answer range 8.9 to 9.1.

step_by_step: Identify the model: uniform flow of speed U_\infty plus a 2-D line source of strength m, giving a Rankine half-body. The stagnation point is on the x-axis upstream of the source.
Write the radial velocity induced by a 2-D source: v_r = m/(2\pi r). Along the x-axis, this is aligned with the streamwise direction.
At the stagnation point (distance s upstream of the source), the uniform flow is exactly cancelled by the source-induced velocity: U_\infty - m/(2\pi s) = 0, giving m/(2\pi) = U_\infty s.
For a point P located a further distance d upstream from the stagnation point, its distance from the source is r_P = s + d. The local x-velocity is u_P = U_\infty - m/(2\pi r_P).
Substitute m/(2\pi) = U_\infty s into u_P to get u_P = U_\infty - U_\infty s/(s + d) = U_\infty d/(s + d).
Impose the condition that at P the velocity is 90% of the freestream: u_P = 0.9 U_\infty. Thus 0.9 = d/(s + d).
Solve the algebraic equation: 0.9(s + d) = d \Rightarrow 0.9s + 0.9d = d \Rightarrow 0.9s = 0.1d \Rightarrow d/s = 9.

topic.name: Inviscid incompressible potential flow (Rankine bodies)
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 2: Aerodynamics -> Incompressible flows, potential flow theory

concepts.name: Velocity field of a 2-D line source
Streamwise velocity recovery in front of a bluff body

essential: Basic potential flow theory for inviscid, incompressible, irrotational flows
Velocity field induced by a 2-D line source in polar coordinates
Concept of stagnation point where local velocity is zero
Algebraic manipulation and solving simple ratios
Understanding of superposition of uniform flow and singularities
helpful: Physical interpretation of Rankine half-body as flow around a blunt body
Coordinate geometry along the axis of symmetry in potential flows

Main Concept: requires: Velocity field of a 2-D source, v_r = m/(2\pi r)
requires: Stagnation condition U_\infty = m/(2\pi s)
enables: Quantitative prediction of velocity distribution around Rankine bodies
enables: More advanced airfoil theory using source/sink distributions

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the correct direction of source-induced velocity along the upstream axis
Needs careful geometric interpretation of distances s and d from the figure
Involves combining stagnation condition with a second velocity condition

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson
textbook_references.section: 3.11 Superposition of elementary flows; Rankine half-body
textbook_references.text_snippet: By combining a uniform flow with a source, we obtain the Rankine half-body. The stagnation point occurs at r = \Lambda/(2\pi V_\infty) on the upstream axis, and the dividing streamline defines the body surface.

video_references.topic_covered: Potential flow: combination of uniform flow and source; Rankine half-body and stagnation streamline

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Write source-induced velocity -> Apply stagnation condition to relate m, U_\infty, s -> Express velocity at point P -> Impose 90% freestream condition -> Solve for d/s
key_insights: On the upstream axis, the source-induced velocity opposes the freestream, leading to a simple 1-D expression for u(x).
The stagnation condition provides a direct relation m/(2\pi) = U_\infty s, eliminating the unknown source strength.
The ratio d/s emerges naturally from the non-dimensional velocity requirement u_P/U_\infty = 0.9.

formulas_principles.name: Radial velocity due to 2-D line source
formulas_principles.conditions: Inviscid, incompressible, irrotational 2-D flow with a point source of strength m at the origin
formulas_principles.relevance: Gives the induced velocity component along the axis used to find stagnation and local velocities.

formulas_principles.name: Stagnation condition for Rankine half-body
formulas_principles.conditions: Applied at the upstream stagnation point where total velocity is zero
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates source strength m to freestream velocity U_\infty and stagnation distance s.

formulas_principles.name: Streamwise velocity at point P
formulas_principles.conditions: Point P lies on the upstream axis at distance s + d from source
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to enforce the 90% velocity recovery condition.

formulas_principles.name: Final ratio of distances
formulas_principles.conditions: Obtained from u_P/U_\infty = 0.9 and stagnation relation

industry_examples: Approximate modeling of flow around blunt-nosed bodies such as capsules or fairings using potential flow plus singularities.
Preliminary design of forebody shapes where inviscid outer flow is approximated by Rankine bodies before adding viscous corrections.
specific_systems: Re-entry capsules and blunt nose cones where stagnation region size affects heating and pressure distribution.
Submarine bows or underwater vehicles where forebody shapes are sometimes analyzed using potential flow analogies.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how velocity recovers upstream of a bluff body helps estimate pressure distributions, drag, and stagnation region size, which are critical for structural loads and thermal protection design.

common_mistakes.mistake: Taking the source-induced velocity along the upstream axis as adding to the freestream (u = U_\infty + m/(2\pi r)) instead of subtracting.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember only the magnitude of v_r and forget to consider the direction of the radial vector relative to the x-axis.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always sketch the radial direction and the positive x-direction. Upstream of the source, the radial direction points upstream, opposite to the freestream, so the velocities subtract.
common_mistakes.consequence: Predicts no stagnation point upstream and gives completely wrong d/s.

common_mistakes.mistake: Misinterpreting distances: using r_P = d instead of r_P = s + d.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on the distance from stagnation point to P and forget that the source is at a different location.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Mark coordinates on a number line: place source at x = 0, stagnation at x = -s, and P at x = -(s + d). Then read off distances from the source.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect algebraic equation and wrong numerical ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not using the stagnation condition to eliminate the unknown source strength m, leading to too many unknowns.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They treat m as an independent parameter and try to solve directly for d/s.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: First always use the stagnation point information to relate m, U_\infty, and s; then analyze other points.
common_mistakes.consequence: Stuck with unsolvable system or unnecessary complexity.

common_mistakes.mistake: Algebraic slip when solving 0.9 = d/(s + d), e.g., getting d/s = 1/9 instead of 9.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write each step explicitly: 0.9(s + d) = d, then group s and d terms carefully.
common_mistakes.consequence: Numerical answer off by a factor of 81.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Sign of source-induced velocity along the upstream axis (it opposes U_\infty)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever combining uniform flow with a source/sink along the axis.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Use stagnation condition first to relate m, U_\infty, and s
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When dealing with Rankine bodies or stagnation points in potential flow.

flashcards.front: What is the radial velocity field of a 2-D line source of strength m at the origin?
flashcards.back: For an inviscid, incompressible 2-D source: $v_r = \dfrac{m}{2\pi r}$, directed radially outward from the source.

flashcards.front: In a Rankine half-body (uniform flow + source), where is the stagnation point located relative to the source?
flashcards.back: On the upstream axis at distance $s = \dfrac{m}{2\pi U_\infty}$ from the source, where the uniform flow is exactly cancelled by the source-induced velocity.

flashcards.front: For uniform flow + source, derive the expression for streamwise velocity at a point P located a distance d upstream from the stagnation point.
flashcards.back: Source at x=0, stagnation at x=-s, P at x=-(s+d). Distance from source: r_P = s + d. Then $u_P = U_\infty - \dfrac{m}{2\pi (s + d)} = U_\infty \dfrac{d}{s + d}$ using $m/(2\pi) = U_\infty s$.

flashcards.front: Along the upstream axis of a source + uniform flow, do the velocities add or subtract? Why?
flashcards.back: They subtract: $u = U_\infty - m/(2\pi r)$. Upstream, the radial direction points opposite to the freestream, so the source-induced velocity opposes U_\infty.

flashcards.front: If at a point P upstream of a Rankine half-body the velocity is 90% of U_\infty, what is d/s?
flashcards.back: Using $u_P/U_\infty = d/(s + d) = 0.9$, solve to get $d/s = 9$.

real_world_context.application: Estimating size of stagnation region in front of blunt bodies in inviscid flow
real_world_context.industry_example: Preliminary design of re-entry capsule forebodies where potential flow gives an outer solution and stagnation distance relates to pressure and heating loads.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating stagnation region size can lead to incorrect predictions of peak pressure and thermal loads, risking structural or thermal protection failure.

real_world_context.application: Hydrodynamic design of underwater vehicles and torpedoes
real_world_context.industry_example: Using Rankine bodies to approximate flow around submarine bows to minimize drag and flow separation.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Poorly estimated forebody flow can increase drag and noise, reducing efficiency and stealth.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: If you recognize the Rankine half-body model, this is a quick 2–3 step algebra problem: write stagnation condition, velocity at P, set equal to 0.9 U_\infty, and solve for d/s.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that as you move far upstream (d >> s), velocity approaches U_\infty, so d/s must be greater than 1; values near 10 are reasonable.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2–3 minutes. Do not overcomplicate with stream functions; stay on the axis and use 1-D velocity expressions.

search_keywords: Rankine half body uniform flow plus source
2D line source velocity field m over 2 pi r
Anderson Fundamentals of Aerodynamics Rankine body
superposition of elementary flows source sink uniform
GATE AE potential flow Rankine half body problem

alternative_methods.name: Complex potential approach
alternative_methods.description: Represent the flow using complex potential $W(z) = U_\infty z + \frac{m}{2\pi} \ln z$. Differentiate to get complex velocity $dW/dz$, then evaluate along the negative real axis (upstream) to obtain the same expression for u(x) and derive d/s.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: General and elegant, extends easily to more complex configurations. Cons: Requires comfort with complex analysis; overkill for this simple axis problem.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when dealing with multiple singularities or when you want to visualize streamlines and equipotentials in the complex plane.

connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: Builds on incompressible, irrotational flow and potential theory, often first introduced in basic fluid mechanics courses.
connections_to_other_subjects.Complex Analysis: Use of complex potentials and conformal mapping to represent 2-D potential flows.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Outer potential flow solutions feed into aerodynamic force calculations for aircraft bodies.
connections_to_other_subjects.Heat Transfer: Stagnation region size influences stagnation-point heat transfer, important in high-speed aerothermodynamics.

deeper_dive_topics: Rankine ovals (uniform flow plus source and sink) and their use in modeling closed bodies
Conformal mapping techniques for airfoil generation (Joukowski transformation)
Effect of viscosity and boundary layers on flows approximated by potential theory
Stagnation-point heat transfer correlations in high-speed flows

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Incompressible flows, potential flow theory, source/sink and vortex models
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual-numerical question linking potential flow singularities with physically meaningful distances and velocity recovery.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed discussion of Rankine half-body, stagnation point location, and stream function, which directly support the derivation. While the exact 90% velocity condition was not in RAG, the necessary base formulas and concepts were present, enabling a straightforward solution.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the maximum half-thickness of the Rankine half-body in terms of source strength and freestream velocity.
Modify the problem to use a source-sink pair (Rankine oval) and ask for the distance between stagnation points.
Ask students to derive the equation of the dividing streamline (body contour) for the Rankine half-body.
Include a viscous correction and ask qualitatively how the stagnation point and velocity recovery would change.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: Consider a 2-D blunt body in an incompressible fluid stream. The flow is irrotational and can be modeled as a linear combination of a uniform flow and a line source (Rankine half body) as shown below. Let s be the distance of the line source from the front stagnation point. Let d be the upstream distance from the stagnation point to the streamwise location (labeled below as P) where the oncoming stream reaches 90% of its undisturbed velocity. Then d/s = ______.
